column13: description_of_topic
Student can explain the following concepts: complexity measures, complexity classes, optimization algorithms, dynamic programming, greedy algorithms, reductions, complex problems.
The student can determine the time complexity of a given algorithm.
The student can design an algorithm with a predetermined upper bound for a given problem.
The student can design an algorithm in one of the three optimization strategies discussed.
The student can analyze a network problem and translate it from a given problem into a network problem.
The student can apply Discrete Fourier Transform to practical examples.
The student can translate a problem into another problem through time-bounded reduction.

The student can analyze algorithmic properties of a problem (for example: requires exhaustive search over a large domain, or is bounded by constant space) on the basis of which predictions can be made about the (im)possibility of designing efficient algorithms.
A technique where a function calls itself in order to solve smaller instances of the same problem.
Divides a problem into smaller subproblems, solves each subproblem independently, and then combines the solutions.
An efficient search algorithm for finding a target value within a sorted array by repeatedly dividing the search interval in half.
A sorting algorithm that follows the divide and conquer strategy by recursively dividing the array into halves, sorting each half, and then merging the sorted halves.
A sorting algorithm that uses the divide and conquer strategy by partitioning the array into smaller subarrays based on a pivot element and recursively sorting each subarray.
A mathematical operation that computes the product of two matrices.
An algorithm for fast multiplication of large numbers using a divide and conquer approach.
An efficient algorithm for computing the discrete Fourier transform and its inverse.
A technique for systematically searching through all possible solutions to find the optimal one, often used in constraint satisfaction problems.
Various algorithms attributed to Carl Friedrich Gauss, often used for solving linear equations and finding determinants.
An algorithm that solves a problem by solving smaller instances of the same problem.
Algorithms used in artificial intelligence for making decisions in games, such as minimax algorithm with alpha-beta pruning.
A problem in combinatorial optimization that asks whether there exists a subset of a given set whose elements sum to a given target value.
An algorithm for finding the longest increasing subsequence in a given sequence of numbers.
A technique used to solve problems by breaking them down into smaller overlapping subproblems and solving each subproblem only once
Finding the nth Fibonacci number using dynamic programming to avoid redundant recursive calls.
Breaking a given text into words such that the concatenation of these words forms the original text, with the minimum number of words.
Determining whether there exists a subset of a given set whose elements sum to a given target value.
Finding the longest subsequence in a given sequence of numbers that is strictly increasing.
Calculating the minimum number of operations (insertion, deletion, substitution) required to transform one string into another.
Finding the largest subset of vertices in a graph such that no two vertices are adjacent (i.e., there are no edges between any two vertices in the subset).
A class of algorithms that make locally optimal choices at each step with the hope of finding a global optimum solution.
Arranging files stored on multiple tapes in a specific order to minimize the total time required to access all files.
A technique used in proving the optimality of greedy algorithms by showing that any optimal solution must have certain properties.
Assigning tasks or jobs to resources such as processors or machines to optimize a certain objective, such as minimizing completion time or maximizing throughput.
A method of data compression that assigns variable-length codes to input characters, with shorter codes assigned to more frequently occurring characters.
Graph algorithms are a fundamental part of computer science, focusing on analyzing and manipulating graphs, which consist of nodes (vertices) connected by edges.
A subgraph of a graph that includes all the vertices of the original graph with the minimum possible number of edges.
A greedy algorithm for finding the minimum spanning tree (MST) of a connected, weighted graph.
Another greedy algorithm for finding the minimum spanning tree (MST) of a connected, weighted graph.
Finding the shortest path between two vertices in a weighted graph, where the path length is the sum of the weights of its edges.
A greedy algorithm for finding the shortest path from a single source vertex to all other vertices in a weighted graph with non-negative edge weights.
Modeling the flow of goods, information, or resources through a network of nodes and edges, where the goal is to maximize or minimize the flow subject to capacity
The relationship between flows in a network and cuts that partition the network into two disjoint sets of vertices.
The theorem states that in a flow network, the maximum flow value through the network equals the minimum cut capacity across all possible cuts of the network.
An algorithm for computing the maximum flow in a flow network by repeatedly augmenting paths from the source to the sink until no more augmenting paths exist.
Finding a set of paths in a graph such that no two paths share a common edge.
Finding a set of paths in a graph such that no two paths share a common vertex.
Finding a maximum matching in a bipartite graph, where each vertex in one set is adjacent to at most one vertex in the other set.
Assigning a set of tasks to a set of resources in a way that optimizes some objective, such as minimizing total cost or maximizing efficiency.
Determining which teams are mathematically eliminated from contention in a baseball league based on the remaining games to be played.
Selecting a subset of jobs from a pool of available jobs to maximize some objective, such as total profit or total satisfaction.
Introduction to linear programming, a method for optimizing a linear objective function subject to linear equality and inequality constraints.
Finding the dual of a linear programming problem, which involves interchanging the roles of variables and constraints to obtain an equivalent problem with different objectives and constraints.
